sp.p: And, I tell you, Captain Armstrong—but always under favour, you being our leader—you are too humane.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Humanity is scarcely counted a fault: if so, 'tis a fault on the right side.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Umph! perhaps not with us. We are robbers.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: And why should robbers lack humanity? They who plunder most respect it as a virtue, and make a shew on't to gild their vices. Lawyers, Physicians, Placemen, all—all plunder and slay, but all pretend to humanity.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: They are Regulars, and plunder by licence.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Then let us Quacks set the regulars a better example.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: This humanity, Captain, is a high horse you are ever bestride upon. Some day, mark my word, he'll fling you.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Cruelty is a more dangerous beast:—When the rider's thrown, his brains are kick'd out, and no one pities him.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Like enough; but your tough horseman, who ventures boldly, is never dismounted. When I am engaged in a desperate chace, (as we are, Captain,) I stick at nothing. I hate milk sops.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: And love mutiny. Take heed, Orson, I have before caution'd you not to glance at me.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: I say nothing: but if some escape to inform against us, whom we have rob'd, 'tis none of my fault. Dead men tell no tales.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Wretch! Speak that again, and you shall tell none. holds a carbine to his head

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Flash away!—I don't fear death.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: More shame for thee; for thou art unfit to meet it.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: I know my trade. I set powder, ball, and rope, at defiance.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Brute! You mistake headstrong insensibility for courage. Do not mistake my horror of it for cowardice: for I, who shudder at cruelty, will fell your boldness to the earth, when I see you practise it. Submit.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: I do. I know not what 'tis, but I have told you, often, there is something about you awes me. I cannot tell—I could kill twenty to your one.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: There 'tis.—Thou wouldst dart upon the weak unguarded man, like a tyger. A ferocious animal, whether crawling or erect, ever slinks from fair opposition.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: My courage was never yet doubted, Captain.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Your nerves, fool. Thou art a mere machine. Could I but give it motion, I would take an oak from the forest, here, clap a flint into it for heart, and make as bold a fellow as thou art. Listen to my orders.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: I obey.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Get thee to our den. Put on thy disguise —then hie thee to the market town for provision, for our company. Here—Here is part of the spoil we took yester-night: see you bring an honest account of what you lay out. giving Money

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: My honour!—

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Well, I do not doubt thee, here. Our profession is singular; its followers do not cheat one another. You will not be back till dusk. See you fall not on any poor straggling peasant, as you return.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: I would fain encounter the solitary man, who is sometimes wandering by night about the forest. He is rich.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Not for your life. 'Tis Sir Edward Mortimer, the head keeper. Touch him not; 'tis too near home. Besides, he is no object for plunder. I have watch'd him, at midnight, stealing from his lodge, to wander like one crazed. He is good, too, to the poor; and should walk unmolested by Charity's charter. 'Twere pity that he who administers to necessity, all day, should be rifled by necessity at night. An thou shouldst meet him, I charge thee spare him.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: I must, if it be your order. This sparing doctrine will go nigh, at last, to starve all the thieves. When a man takes to the trade of a wolf, he should not go like a lamb to his business. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: This fellow is a downright villain: Harden'd and relentless. I have felt, in my penury, the world trample on me. It has driven me to take that, desperately, which wanting I should starve. Death! my spirit cannot brook to see a sleek knave walk negligently by his fellow in misery, and suffer him to rot. I will wrench that comfort from him which he will not bestow.—But nature puts a bar:—Let him administer to my wants, and pass on:—I have done with him.

lg.l: When the Robber his victim has noted,
When the Free-booter darts on his prey,
Let humanity spare the devoted;
Let Mercy forbid him to slay.
Since my hope is by penury blighted,
My sword must the traveller daunt;
I will snatch from the rich man, benighted,
The gold he denies to my want.
But the victim when, once, I have noted,
At my foot, when I look on my prey,
Let Humanity spare the devoted;
Let mercy forbid me to slay.

div2.stage: The Hall in SIR EDWARD MORTIMER's Lodge.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, business must be minded:—but he stays
A tedious time, methinks.—You fellow!

div2.stage: To a servant crossing the hall.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Where is Sir Tristful? Where's Don Melancholy?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Who, sir?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: My brother, knave, Sir Edward Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He was with you, but now, sir

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Sir, I thank you;—
That's information. Louts, and serving-men,
Can never parley straight. I met a fellow,
Here, in my way across the heath,—a Hind—
And ask'd how far to Lymington: I look'd
The answer would have bolted from his chops,
Bounce, like a pellet from a popgun.—No:—
He stared, and scratch'd his empty head, and cried,
"Where do you come from?"—Who brought in my luggage?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: It was not I, sir,

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: There!—They never can!
Go to your master; pray him to dispatch
His houshold-work:—tell him I hate fat Folios.
Plague! when I cross the country, here, to see him,
He leaves me ram'd into an elbow chair,
With a huge, heavy book, that makes me nod,
Then tumbles on my toes. Tell him, do'st hear,
Captain Fitzharding's company has tired me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Whose company?—

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: My own, knave.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, I shall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: A book to me's a sovereign Narcotick;
A lump of opium; every line a dose.
Edward is all deep reading, and black letter;
He shews it in his very chin. He speaks
Mere Dictionary; and he pores on pages
That gives plain men the head-ach. "Scarce, and curious,"
Are baits his learning nibbles at. His brain
Is cram'd with mouldy volumes, cramp, and useless,
Like a librarian's lumber-room.—Poor fellow!
Grief will do much!—well! some it drives to reading,
And some to drinking;—'twill do much!—this trial—
A fool to fret so for't! his honour's clear.
Tut! I'm a soldier—know what honour is.
Had I been slander'd, and a fair Court martial
Cleansed me from calumny, as white as snow,
I had ne'er moped, and fumed, and winced, and kick'd,
But sat down heart-whole. Plague upon't! this house
Appears the very cave of melancholy.
Nay, hold, I lie:—here comes a petticoat.
Od! a rare wench! This is the best edition
In Edward's whole collection. Here, come hither!
Let me peruse you.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Would you speak with me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Ave. child. I'm going now to read you.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: Read me!
You'll find me full of errors, sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: No matter.
Come nearer, child: I cannot see to read
At such a distance.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: You had better, sir,
Put on your spectacles.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye, there she has me!
A plague upon old Time! old scythe and hourglass
Has set his mark upon me. Harkve, child:
You do not know me. You and I must have
Better acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: O, I've heard of you.
You are Sir Edward's kinsman, Sir—his brother.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye—his half brother—by the mother's side—
His elder brother.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I see that.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: This gypsey's tongue is like her eye; I know not
Which is the sharpest. Tell me what's your name.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: My name is Blanch, Sir—born, here, in the forest.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Sbud! I must be a Keeper in this forest. Whither art going, sweet one?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Home, sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Home!
Why is not this thy home?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: No, Sir; I live
Some half mile hence—with madam Helen, sir.
I brought a letter from her, to Sir Edward.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Odso, with Helen!—so—with her!—the object
Of my grave brother's groaning passion. Plague!
I would 'twere in the house. I do not like
Your rheumatick, October assignations,
Under an elm, by moonlight. This will end
In flannels and sciatica. My passion
Is not Arcadian. Tell me, pretty one,
Shall I walk with you, home?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: No, Sir, I thank you;
It would fatigue you, sadly.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Fatigue me!
Oons! this wild forest filly, here, would make me
Grandfather to Methusaleh. Look here—
Here is a purse of money

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: O, the father!
What will you give me any?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Gold I find
The universal key; the passe par tout.
It will unlock a forest maiden's heart,
As easy as a politician's. Here;
Here are two pieces, rose-bud. Buy a top-knot;
Make thyself happy with them.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: That I will.
The poor old woman, northward of the lodge,
Lies sick in bed. I'll take her this, poor soul,
To comfort her,

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Hold!—hey! the devil!—hold.
This was not meant to comfort an old woman.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Why, would'nt you relieve her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Um?—yes;—
But—pshaw? pooh, prithee—there's a time for all things.
Why tell me of her now,—of an old fool,—
Of comforting the aged, now?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: I thought
That you might have a fellow feeling, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: This little pastoral devil's laughing at me!
Oons! come and kiss me, jade. I am a Soldier,
And Justice of the Peace.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: Then, shame upon you!
Your double calling might have taught you better.
I see your drift now. Take your dirt again,
Good Captain-Justice!—Stoop for it,—and think
How an old Soldier, and a Justice, looks,
When he is picking up the bribes he offers,
To injure those he should protect;—the helpless,
The poor, and innocent. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I warrant me,
Could I but see my face now, in a glass,
That I look wond'rous sheepish. I'm ashamed
To pick up the two pieces.—Let them lye,—
I would not wrong the innocent;—good reason;—
There be so few that are so;—she is honest;
I must make reparation. Odso! Wilford!
How fares it, boy?

sp.speaker: Wilford.
sp.l: I thank you, sir. I hope you have enjoy'd
Your health, these three months past, since last you honour'd us
With your good presence at the lodge

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Indifferent.
Some cramps and shooting pains, boy. I have dropt
Some cash here, but I am afraid to bend
To pick it up again, lest it should give me
An aukward twinge. Stoop for it, honest Wilford.
There's a good lad!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Right willingly Sir. Picks up the money.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: So!
The Soldier and the Justice save their blushes.—
Now, carry it, I prithee, at your leisure,
To an old gossip, near the lodge here—northward—
I've heard of her—she's bed-ridden, and sick.
You reed not say who sent you.
I conceive.
'Tis private bounty; that's true charity.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Nay, pish!—my charity!—

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Nay, I could swear
'Tis not the first time you have offered this
In secret.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Um!—why no;—not quite the first.
But tell me, lad, how jogs the world here, eh?
In Rueful Castle?—What, some three months back,
We two were cronies. What hast thou forgot?
Thou wert my favourite here, man.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Sir, you honour'd me
By saying so.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Tut! honour'd!—tut—a fig!
Thou art grown starch and sad. This air is catching;
Thou art infected. Harkye, Wilford, harkye!
Thou'rt a sly rogue! What you could never tell me
Of Helen's waiting maid; the little cherry;—
Of—plague upon her name!—of—

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Blanch, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Blanch:
That's it;—the forest fairy.—You and I
Must have some talk about her.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Have you seen her?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Just now: just gone. Od! I have blunder'd horribly!
You must know, lad—come hither.

div2.stage: They retire to the back of the scene.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Now for my brother, and—Ha! Wilford with him!
That imp is made my scourge. They whisper too.
O! I had rather court the thunder-bolt,
To melt my bones, and pound me to a mass,
Than suffer this vile canker to corrode me.
Wilford!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Who calls?—eh!—'tis sir Edward.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Mum!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I seem to interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: earnestly No, indeed.
No, on my life, sir:—we were only talking
Of—

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Hold your tongue. Oons! boy, you must not tell.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Not!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Not! not to be sure:—why, 'tis a secret.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: You shall know all, sir.—'Twas a trifle— nothing—
In faith you shall know all.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: In faith you lie.
Be satisfied, good Edward:—'tis a toy.—
But, of all men, I would not have thee know on't.
It is a tender subject.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Aye, indeed!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: May not I have my secret? Oons! good brother,
What would you say, now, should a meddling knave
Busy his brains with matters, though but trivial,
Which concern you alone?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: I'd have him rot:
Die piecemeal; pine; moulder in misery.
Agent, and sacrifice to Heaven's wrath,
When castigating plagues are hurl'd on man,
Stands lean, and lynx-eyed Curiosity,
Watching his neighbour's soul. Sleepless himself
To banish sleep from others. Like a Leech
Sucking the blood-drops from a care-worn heart,
He gorges on't—then renders up his food,
To nourish Calumny, his foul-lung'd mate,
Who carries Rumour's trumpet; and whose breath,
Infecting the wide surface of the world,
Strikes pestilence and blight. O, fie ont! fie!
Whip me the curious wretch from pole to pole!
Who writhes in fire, and scorches all around him,
A victim making victims!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: By the mass,
'Twere a sound whipping that, from pole to pole!
From constable to constable might serve.
E'en you yourself were like to prove, but now,
This Leech, that's yoke-fellow, you say, to Scandal,
The bad-breath'd trumpeter.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Your pardon, brother;
I had forgot. Wilford, I've business for you.
Wait for me—aye—an hour after dinner,
Wait for me in the library.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: The library!—
I sicken at the sound. aside. Wait there for you— and—
Captain Fitzharding, sir?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: For me. alone.

sp.speaker: Wilf
sp.p: Alone, sir!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Yes,—begone.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I shall, sir—but
If I have ever breath'd a syllable
That might displease you may—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Fool! breathe no more.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I'm dumb.
I'd rather step into a Lion's den
Than meet him in the library!—I go, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Brother, you are too harsh with that poor boy.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Brother, a man must rule his family
In his own way.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, well, well—Don't be touchy.
I speak not to offend: I only speak
On a friend's privilege. The poor are men,
And have their feelings, brother.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: So have I!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: One of the best that we can shew, believe me,
Is mildness to a servant. Servants, brother,
Are born with fortune's yoke about their necks;
And that is galling in itself enough;
We should not goad them under it. The master
Should rather cheer them in their servitude,
With kindly words—not too familiar neither;
But utter'd with that air which true benevolence
Imparts to dignified nobility.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Brother, your hand. You have a gentle nature—
May no mischance e'er ruffle it, my brother!
I've known thee from my infancy, old soldier;
And never did I know—I do not flatter—
A heart more stout, more cased with hardy manhood,
More full of milk within. Trust me, dear friend,
If admiration of thy charity
May argue charity in the admirer,
I am not destitute.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: You!—I have seen you
Sometimes o'erflow with it.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: And what avails it?
Honour has been my theme; good will to man
My study. I have labour'd for a name
As white as mountain snow; dazzling, and speckless:
Shame on't! 'tis blur'd with blots! Fate, like a mildew,
Ruins the virtuous harvest I would reap,
And all my crop is weeds.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Why, how now, brother!
This is all spleen. You mope yourself too much,
In this dull forest, here. Twenty blue devils
Are dancing jigs, and hornpipes, in your brains.
Fie, fie! be more a man.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Well, I have done.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Come, what's for dinner? Od! I mean to eat
Abundantly.

sp.speaker: Mort
sp.l: I know not, brother. Honest Winterton
Will tell you all.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: What he! old Adam! he!
My merry buck of Paradise?—Odso!:
I have not seen him. Well, he shall produce
A flaggon of the best; and, after dinner,
We will be jovial▪ Come, come, rouse you, man!
I came on purpose, thirty miles from home,
To jog your spirits. Prithee, now, be gay!
And, prithee, too, be kind to my young favourite!
To Wilford there.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Well, well; I hope I have been.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: No doubt, in actions:—but in words and looks —
A rugged look's a damper to a greenhorn.
I watch'd him, now, when you frown'd angerly:
And he betray'd—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Betray'd!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Ten thousand fears.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: The poor devil couldn't shew more scared
Had you e'en held a pistol to his head.
Why hey-day! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Brother I —
Question me not; my nerves are aspin-like;
The slightest breath will shake 'em. Come, good brother.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: You'll promise to be gay?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Why that's well said! A man can do no more.
Od! I believe my ratling talk has given you
A stir already.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: That it has indeed!
Come, brother!

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Are you he that wish to enter in my service?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Yes, so please you, Madam Helen, for want of a better.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Why, I have seen you in the forest— at Rawbold's cottage. He is your father, as I think.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Yes, so please you, Madam; for want of a better.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: I fear me you may well say that. Your father, as I have heard, bears an ill name, in the forest.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Alas! madam he is obliged to bear it— for want of a better. We are all famish'd, madam: and the naked and hungry have seldom many friends to speak well of them.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: If I should hire thee, who will give thee a character?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: My father, madam.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Why sirrah, he has none of his own.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: The more fatherly in him, madam, to give his son what he has need of, for himself. But a knave is often applied to, to vouch for a good servant's honesty. I will serve you as faithfully as your last footman; who, I have heard, ran away this morning.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Truly, he did so.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: I was told on't, some half hour ago; and ran, hungrily, hither, to offer myself. So, please you, let not poverty stand in the way of my preferment.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Should I entertain you, what could you do to make yourself useful?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Any thing. I can wire hares, snare partridges, shoot a buck, and smuggle brandy, for you, madam.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Fie on you, knave! 'Twere fitter to turn you over to the Verderors of the forest, for punishment, than to encourage you in such practices.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: I would practise any thing better, that might get me bread. I would scrape trenchers, fill buckets, and carry a message. What can a man do! He can't starve.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Well, sirrah, to snatch thee from evil, I care not if I make trial of thee?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: No! will you?

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Nineteen in twenty might question my prudence for this:—but, whatever loss I may suffer from thy roguery, the thought of having open'd a path to lead a needy wanderer back to virtue, will more than repay me.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: O, bless you, lady! If I do not prove virtuous never trust in man more. I am overjoy'd!

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Get thee to the kitchen. You will find a lively there will suit you.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: A livery! O, the father! Virtuous and a livery, all in a few seconds! Heaven bless you!

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Well, get you to your work.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I go, madam. If I break any thing to day, beseech you let it go for nothing; for joy makes my hand tremble. Should you want me please to cry Samson, and I am with you in a twinkling. Heaven bless you! Here's fortune▪ Exit.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Blanch stays a tedious time. Heaven send Mortimer's health be not worse! He is sadly altered since we came to the forest. I dream'd last night, of the fire he saved me from; and I saw him, all fresh, in manly bloom, bearing me through the flames, even as it once happened.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: How now, wench! You have almost tired my patience.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: And my own legs, madam. If the old faotman had not made so much use of his, by running away, they might have spared mine.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Inform me of Sir Edward Mortimer.
Hast seen him?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Yes, I have, madam.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Say; tell me;
How look'd he? how's his health? is he in spirits?
What said he, Blanch? Will he be here to day?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: A little breath, madam, and I will answer all duly.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: O! fie up in thee, wench!
These interrogatories should be answered
Quicker than breath can utter them.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: That's impossible, lady.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Thou would'st not say so hadst thou ever lov'd.
Love has a fleeter messenger than speech,
To tell love's meaning. His expresses post
Upon the orbs of vision, ere the tongue
Can shape them into words. A lover's look
Is his heart's Mercury. O! the Eye's eloquence,
Twin-born with thought, outstrips the tardy voice,
Far swifter than the nimble lightning's flash
The sluggish thunder-peal that follows it.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I am not skill'd in eye-talking, madam. I have been used to let my discourse ride upon my tongue, and, I have been told, 'twill trot at a good round pace upon occasion.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Then let it gallop, now, beseech you, wench,
And bring me news of Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Then, madam, I saw Sir Edward in his library: and deliver'd your letter. He will be here either in the evening, or on the morrow: 'tis uncertain which—for his brother, Capt. Fitzharding, is arrived on a visit to him.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Is he?—well, that may somewhat raise his spirits.
That soldier has a pleasant, harmless mind.
Mirth gilds his age, and sits upon his brow
Like sun in winter. I ne'er saw a man
More cheerful in decline, more laughter-loving,
More gay, and frolicksome.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Frolicksome enough, if you knew all— but not so harmless. aside

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: He'll scarce be here to night.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Who? Sir Edward? Haply not, madam: but his letter may chance to specify further particulars.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: His letter! Has he written?—fie upon thee!
Why didst not give it me, at once? Where is it?
Thou art turn'd dreamer, wench!—Come, quickly.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: You talk'd to me so much of reading eyes, madam, that I e'en forgot the letter. Here it is.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Come to me, shortly, in my cabinet:
I'll read it there.—I am almost unfit
To open it. I ne'er receive his letters
But my hand trembles. Well, I know 'tis silly,
And yet I cannot help it. I will ring;
Then come to me, good Blanch—not yet. My Mortimer,
Now for your letter!Exit.

sp.speaker: Blanch
sp.p: I would they were wedded once, and all this trembling would be over. I am told your married lady's feelings are little roused in reading letters from a husband.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: This sudden turn of fortune might puff some men up with pride. I have look'd in the glass already:—and if ever man look'd braver in a glass than I, I know nothing of finery.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Hey day! who have we here?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh, lord! this is the maid.—I mean the waiting-woman. I warrant we shall be rare company, in a long winter's evening.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Why, who are you?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I'm your fellow-servant:—the new comer. The last footman cast his skin in the pantry this morning, and I have crept into it.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Why, sure, it cannot be!—Now I look upon you again, you are Samson Rawbold—old Rawbold's son, of the forest here.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The same; I am not like some upstarts; When I am prosperous, I do not turn my back on my poor relations.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: What, has my lady hired thee?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: She has taken me, like a pad nag, upon trial.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I suspect you will play her a jade's trick, and stumble in your probation. You have been caught tripping, ere now.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: An I do not give content 'tis none of my fault. A man's qualities cannot come out all at once. I wish you would teach me a little how to lay a cloth.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: You are well qualified for your office truly, not to know that!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: To say truth, we had little practice that way at home. We stood not upon forms. We had sometimes no cloth for a dinner.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: And, sometimes, no dinner for a cloth.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Just so. We had little order in our family.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Well, I will instruct you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: That's kind. I will be grateful. They tell me I have learnt nothing but wickedness yet: but I will instruct you in any thing I know, in return.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: There I have no mind to become your scholar. But be steady in your service, and you may outlive your beggary, and grow into respect.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Nay, an riches rain upon me, respect will grow of course. I never knew a rich man yet who wanted followers to pull off their caps to him.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: A traveller stopt at a widow's gate;
She kept an Inn, and he wanted to bait;—
But the landlady slighted her guest:
For when Nature was making an ugly race,
She certainly moulded this traveller's face
As a sample for all the rest.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The chamber-maid's sides they were ready to crack,
When she saw his queer nose, and the hump at his back;—
A hump is'nt handsome, no doubt—
And though 'tis confess'd, that the prejudice goes,
Very strongly, in favour of wearing a nose,
Yet a nose should'nt look like a snout.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: A bag full of gold on the table he laid—
'T had a wond'rous effect on the widow and maid!
And they quickly grew marvellous civil.
The money immediately alter'd the case;
They were charm'd with his hump, and his snout, and his face,
Tho' he still might have frighted the devil.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: He paid like a prince—gave the widow a smack—
Then stop'd on his horse, at the door, like a sack;
While the landlady, touching the chink,
Cried—"Sir, should you travel this country again,
"I heartily hope that the sweetest of men
"Will stop at the widow's to drink"Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE IV.—

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: I would Sir Edward were come! The dread of a fearful encounter is, often, as terrible as the encounter itself. Yet my encounters with him, of late, are no trifles. Some few hours back, in this very room, he held a loaded pistol within an inch of my brains. Well, that was passion—he threw it from him on the instant, and—eh!—He's coming.— No. The old wainscot cracks, and frightens me out of my wits: and, I verily believe, the great folio dropt on my head, just now, from the shelf, on purpose to encrease my terrors.

div2.stage: Enter Sir EDWARD MORTIMER, at one door of the Library, which he locks after him. WILFORD turns round on hearing him shut it.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: What's that?—'Tis he himself! Mercy on me! he has lock'd the door!—What is going to become of me!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Wilford!—Is no one in the picture-gallery?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: No—not a soul, Sir—Not a human soul.—
None within hearing, if I were to bawl
Ever so loud.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Lock yonder door.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: The door, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Do as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: What, Sir? Lock— Mortimer waves with his hand
I shall, Sir. going to the door and locking it
His face has little anger in it, neither:
'Tis rather mark'd with sorrow, and distress.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Wilford, approach me.—What am I to say
For aiming at your life!—Do you not scorn me,
Despise me for it?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: I! Oh, Sir!—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: You must.
For I am singled from the herd of men,
A vile, heart-broken wretch!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed, Sir,
You deeply wrong yourself. Your equal's love,
The poor man's prayer, the orphan's tear of gratitude,
All follow you:—and I!—I owe you all!
I am most bound to bless you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Mark me, Wilford.—
I know the value of the orphan's tear,
The poor man's prayer, respect from the respected;
I feel to merit these, and to obtain them,
Is to taste here, below, that thrilling cordial
Which the remunerating Angel draws,
From the eternal fountain of delight,
To pour on blessed souls, that enter heaven.
I feel this:—I!—How must my nature, then,
Revolt at him who seeks to stain his hand,
In human blood?—and yet it seems, this day,
I sought your life.—O! I have suffer'd madness—
None know my tortures—pangs!—but I can end them:
End them as far as appertains to thee.—
I have resolv'd it.—Hell-born struggles tear me!
But I have ponder'd on't,—and I must trust thee.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Your confidence shall not be—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: You must swear.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Swear, Sir!—will nothing but an oath, then—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Listen.
May all the ills that wait on frail humanity
Be doubled on your head, if you disclose
My fatal secret! May your body turn
Most lazar-like, and loathsome; and your mind
More loathsome than your body! May those fiends
Who strangle babes, for very wantonness,
Shrink back, and shudder at your monstrous crimes,
And, shrinking, curse you! Palsies strike your youth!
And the sharp terrors of a guilty mind
Poison your aged days; while all your nights,
As on the earth you lay your houseless head,
Out-horror horror! May you quit the world
Abhor'd, self-hated, hopeless for the next,
Your life a burthen, and your death a fear!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: For mercy's sake, forbear! you terrify me!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Hope this may fall upon thee;—Swear thou hopest it,
By every attribute which heaven, earth, hell,
Can lend, to bind, and strengthen conjuration,
If thou betray'st me.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Well I— hesitating.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: No retreating!

sp.speaker: Wilf.

l.hi: I swear, by all the ties that bind a man,

sp.l: Divine, or human,—never to divulge!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Remember you have sought this secret.
—Yes,
Extorted it. I have not thrust it on you.
'Tis big with danger to you; and to me,
While I prepare to speak, torment unutterable.
Know, Wilford that—damnation!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Dearest Sir!
Collect yourself. This shakes you horribly.
You had this trembling, it is scarce a week,
At Madam Helen's.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: There it is.—Her Uncle!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Her uncle!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Him. She knows it not—None know it—
You are the first ordained to hear me say,
I am—his murderer.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: O, heaven!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: His assassin.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: What you that—mur—the murder— I am choak'd!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Honour, thou blood—stain'd God! at whose red altar
Sit War and Homicide, O, to what madness
Will insult drive thy votaries! By heaven,
In the world's range there does not breathe a man
Whose brutal nature I more strove to soothe,
With long forbearance, kindness, courtesy,
Than his who fell by me. But he disgraced me,
Stain'd me,—oh, death, and shame!—the world look'd on,
And saw this sinewy savage strike me down;
Rain blows upon me, drag me to and fro,
On the base earth, like carrion, Desperation,
In every fibre of my frame, cried vengeance!
I left the room, which he had quitted. Chance
(Curse on the chance!) while boiling with my wrongs,
Thrust me against him, darkling, in the street:—
I stab'd him to the heart:—and my oppressor
Roll'd, lifeless, at my foot.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Oh! mercy on me!
How could this deed be cover'd!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Would you think it?
E'en at the moment when I gave the blow,
Butcher'd a fellow-creature in the dark,
I had all good mens love. But my disgrace,
And my opponent's death, thus link'd with it,
Demanded notice of the magistracy.
They summon'd me, as friend would summon friend,
To acts of import, and communication.
We met: and 'twas resolved, to stifle rumour,
To put me on my trial. No accuser,
No evidence appeared, to urge it on.—
'Twas meant to clear my fame.—How clear it, then?
How cover it? you say.—Why, by a Lie:
Guilt's offspring, and its guard. I taught this breast,
Which Truth once made her throne, to forge a lie;
This tongue to utter it.—Rounded a tale,
Smooth as a Seraph's song from Satan's mouth;
So well compacted, that the o'er throng'd court
Disturb'd cool justice, in her judgment-seat,
By shouting "Innocence!" ere I had finish'd.
The Court enlarged me; and the giddy rabble
Bore me, in triumph, home. Aye!—look upon me!—
I know thy sight aches at me.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Heaven forgive me!
I think I love you still:—but I am young;
I know not what to say:—it may be wrong.—
Indeed I pity you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: I disdain all pity.—
I ask no consolation. Idle boy!
Think'st thou that this compulsive confidence
Was given to move thy pity?—Love of fame
(For still I cling to it) has urged me, thus,
To quash thy curious mischief in its birth.
Hurt honour, in an evil, cursed hour,
Drove me to murder—lying:—'twould again.
My honesty,—sweet peace of mind,—all, all!
Are barter'd for a name. I will maintain it.
Should slander whisper o'er my sepulchre,
And my soul's agency survive in death,
I could embody it with heaven's lightning,
And the hot shaft of my insulted spirit
Should strike the blaster of my memory
Dead in the church-yard. Boy, I would not kill thee:
Thy rashness and discernment threaten'd danger:
To check them there was no way left but this:
Save one—your death:—you shall not be my victim.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: My death! What take my life?—My life! to prop
This empty honour.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Empty! Groveling fool!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I am your servant, Sir: child of your bounty;
And know my obligation. I have been
Too curious, haply; 'tis the fault of youth.
I ne'er meant injury: if it would serve you,
I would lay down my life; I'd give it freely:—
Could you, then, have the heart to rob me of it?
You could not;—should not.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: You dare not.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Dare not!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Some hours ago you durst not. Passion moved you;
Reflection interposed, and held your arm.
But, should reflection prompt you to attempt it,
My innocence would give me strength to struggle,
And wrest the murderous weapon from your hand.
How would you look to find a peasant boy
Return the knife you level'd at his heart;
And ask you which in heaven would shew the best,
A rich man's honour, or a poor man's honesty?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: 'Tis plain I dare not take your life. To spare it,
I have endanger'd mine. But dread my power;—
You know not its extent. Be warn'd in time:
Trifle not with my feelings. Listen, Sir!
Myriads of engines, which my secret working
Can rouse to action, now encircle you.
I speak not vaguely. You have heard my principle;
Have heard, already, what it can effect:
Be cautious how you thwart it. Shun my brother;
Your ruin hangs upon a thread: Provoke me,
And it shall fall upon you. Dare to make
The slightest movement to awake my fears,
And the gaunt criminal, naked and stake-tied,
Left on the heath to blister in the sun,
'Till lingering death shall end his agony,
Compared to thee, shall seem more enviable
Than Cherubs to the damn'd.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: O, misery!
Discard me sir! I must be hateful to you.
Banish me hence. I will be mute as death;
But let me quit your service.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Never.—Fool!
To buy this secret, you have sold yourself.
Your movements, eyes, and, most of all, your breath,
From this time forth, are fetter'd to my will.
You have said, truly: you are hateful to me:
Yet you shall feel my bounty:—that shall flow,
And swell your fortunes; but my inmost soul
Will yearn with loathing, when—hark! some one knocks!
Open the door.

div2.stage: Wilford opens the door, and Winterton comes in.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: How now, Winterton?
Did you knock more than once? Speak—did you listen—
—I mean, good Adam, did you wait?—Aye, wait
Long at the door, here?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Bless your honour! no.
You are too good to let the old man wait.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: What, then, our talk, here—Wilford's here and mine—
Did not detain you at the door?—Ha!—did it?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Not half-a-second.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Oh!—well, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Capt. Fitzharding, Sir, entreats your company.
I've placed another flaggon on the table.
Your worship knows it.—Number thirty-five:—
The supernaculum.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Well, well.—I come.
What, has he been alone?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: No—I've been with him.
Od! he's a merry man! and does so jest!
He calls me first of men, 'cause my name's Adam.
Well! 'tis exceeding pleasant, by Sr. Thomas!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Come, Adam; I'll attend the Captain. —Wilford,
What I have just now given you in charge,
Be sure to keep fast lock'd. I shall be angry,—
Be very angry, if I find you careless.
Follow me, Adam.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p:
This house is no house for me. Fly I will, I am resolved:—but whither? His threats strike terror into me; and were I to reach the pole, I doubt whether I should elude his grasp. But to live here a slave—slave to his fears,—his jealousies! Night's coming on. Darkness be my friend! for I will forth
instantly. The thought of my innocence will cheer me as I wander through the gloom. Oh! when guilty Ambition writhes upon his couch, why should bare-foot Integrity repine, though his sweet sleep be canopied with a ragged hovel!Exit.

div2.head: SCENE V.—
div2.stage: The inside of an Abbey, in ruins. Part of it converted into an habitation for Robbers. Various entrances to their apartment, through the broken arches of the building, &c. &c.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Well, sirrah! have you been upon the scout? Are any of our gang returning?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, Judith! not a soul.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: The rogues tarry thus to fret me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, indeed, Judith, the credit of your cookery is lost among thieves. They never come punctual to their meals.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: No tidings of Orson yet, from the market town?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I have seen nothing of him,

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Brat! thou dost never bring me good news.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Judith, you are ever so cross with me!

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: That wretch Orson slights my love of late. Hence, you hemp-seed, hence! Get to the broken porch of the abbey, and watch. 'Tis all you are good for.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You know I am but young yet, Judith, but with good instructions, I may be a robber in time.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Away, you imp! you will never reach such preferment. A whistle without. So! I hear some of our party Whistle again. The Boy puts his fingers in his mouth, and whistles in answer.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Why must you keep your noise, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Nay, Judith, 'tis one of the first steps we boys learn in the profession. I shall ne'er come to good, if you check me so. Huzza! here come two!

div2.stage: Enter two Robbers, through the broken part of the Scene.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: So! you have found your road at last. A murrain light upon you! is it thus you keep your hours!

sp.speaker: 1st Rob.
sp.p: What, hag, ever at this trade! Ever grumbling?

sp.speaker: Jub.
sp.p: I have reason. I toil to no credit; I watch with no thanks. I trim up the table for your return, and no one returns in due time to notice my industry. Your meat is scorch'd to cinders. Rogues, would it were poison for you!

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: How the fury raves! Here, take my carbine; 'twas levell'd, some half hour since, at a traveller's head.

sp.speaker: Jub.
sp.p: Hah, hah, hah! Rare! Didst shoot him?

sp.speaker: 1st Rob.
sp.p: Shoot him? No. This devil in petticoats thinks no more of slaying a man, than killing a cockchafer. I never knew a woman turn to mischief, that she did not outdo a man, clean.

sp.speaker: Jub.
sp.p: Did any of you meet Orson on your way?

sp.speaker: 1st Rob.
sp.p: Aye, there the hand points. When that fellow is abroad you are more savage than customary; and that is needless.

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: None of our comrades come yet? They will be finely soak'd.

sp.speaker: 1st Rob.
sp.p: Aye, the rain pours like a spout upon the ruins of the old abbey wall here.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I'm glad on't. May it drench them, and breed agues! 'twill teach them to keep time.

sp.speaker: 1st Rob.
sp.p: Peace! thou abominable railer. A man had better dwell in purgatory, than have thee in his habitation.—Peace, devil! or I'll make thee repent.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: You! 'tis as much as thy life is worth to move my spleen.

sp.speaker: 1st Rob.
sp.p: What, you will set Orson, your champion, upon me?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Coward! he should not disgrace himself with chastising thee.

sp.speaker: 1st Rob.
sp.p: Death and thunder!—

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Aye, attack a woman, do! it suits your hen-hearted valour. Assault a woman!

sp.speaker: 1st Rob.
sp.p: Well—passion hurried roe. But I have a respect for the soft sex, and am cool again. Come, Judith, be friends.—Nay, come, do; and I will give thee a farthingale, I took from a lawyer's widow.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: 1st Rob.
sp.p: You shall have it.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Well—I— Hark!

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: Soft! I think I hear the foot of a comrade.

lg.head: MUSICAL DIALOGUE AND CHORUS.
lg.l: Listen! No; it is the owl,
That hoots upon the mould'ring tow'r.
Hark! the rain beats, the night is foul!
Our comrades stay beyond their hour.
Listen!
All's hush'd around the abbey wall.—
Soft! Now I hear the robber's call!
Listen!
They whistle!—Answer it!——'Tis nigh!
Again! A comrade comes.—'Tis I!
And here another; and here another!
Who comes! A brother. Who comes?
A brother.
Now they all come pouring in;
Our jollity will soon begin.
Sturdy partners, all appear!
We're here! and here, and here, and here!
Thus we stout freebooters prowl,
Then meet to drain the flowing bowl!

stage.hi: At different periods of the Musick, the Robbers enter, through various parts of Ruins, in groups.

div2.stage: Enter ORSON, with Luggage on his Back, as if return'd from the Market.

sp.speaker: 1st. Rob.
sp.p: See! hither comes Orson at last. He walks in like Plenty, with provision on his shoulder.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: O, Orson!—why did'st tarry, Orson? I began to fear. Thou art cold and damp. Let me wring the wet from thy cloaths. O! my heart leaps to see hee.

sp.speaker: 1st Rob.
sp.p: Mark how this she-bear hugs her bruin!

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Stand off! This hamper has been wearisome enough. I want not thee on my neck.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Villain! 'tis thus you ever use me. I can revenge:—I can—do not, dear Orson! do not treat me thus.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Let a man be ever so sweet temper'd, he will meet somewhat to sour it. I have been vex'd to madness.

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: How now, Orson, what has vex'd thee now?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: A prize has slipt through my fingers.

sp.speaker: 3d Rob.
sp.p: Aye! marry, how?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: I met a straggling knave on foot, and the rogue resisted. He had the face to tell me that he was thrust on the world to seek his fortune; and that the little he had about him was his all. Plague on the provision at my back! I had no time to rifle him: —but I have spoil'd him for fortune seeking, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Why I beat him to the ground. Whether he will e'er get up again the next passenger may discover.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Ha! Ha! O, brave,! That's my valiant Orson!

sp.speaker: 3d. Rob.
sp.p: Orson, you are ever disobeying our Captain's order. You are too remorseless and bloody.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Take heed, then, how you move my anger, by telling me on't. The affair is mine—I will answer to the consequence.

sp.speaker: 4th. Rob.
sp.p: I hear our Captain's signal. Here he comes. Ha!—he is leading one who seems wounded.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Gently, good fellow! come, keep a good heart!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: You are very kind. I had breathed my last, but for your care. Whither have you led me?

sp.speaker: 4th. Rob.
sp.p: Where you will be well treated, youngster. You are now among as honourable a knot of men as ever cried "stand" to a traveller.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: How: among robbers!

sp.speaker: 4th. Rob.
sp.p: Why so the law's cant calls us gentlemen who live at large.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: So! for what am I reserved!

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Fear nothing. You are safe in this asylum. Judith, lead him in. See some of my linen ready, and look to his wound.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I do not like the office. You are ever at these tricks. 'Twill ruin us in the end. What have we to do with charity?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Turbulent wretch! obey me.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Well, I shall. Come, fellow, since it must be so.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Anon, I'll visit you myself, lad.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Heaven bless you! whate'er becomes of my life—and faith, I am almost weary on't—I am bound to your charity. Gently, I pray you—my wound pains. Gently!

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: I would I knew which of you had done this.

sp.speaker: 1st. Rob.
sp.p: Wdy what's the matter, Captain?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Cruelty is the matter. Had not accident led me to the spot where he lay, you poor boy had bled to death. I learn'd his story, partly, from him,
on the way: and know how basely he has been handled by one of you. Well, time must discover him: for he, who had brutality enough to commit the action, can scarcely have courage enough to confess it.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Courage, Captain, is a quality, I take it, little wanted by any here. What signify words—I did it.

sp.speaker: Arm▪
sp.p: I suspected thee, Orson. 'Tis scarce an hour since he, whom thou hast wounded, quitted the service of Sir Edward Mortimer, in the forest, here; and enquiry will doubtless be made.

sp.speaker: 2d. Rob.
sp.p: Nay then we are discover'd.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Now, mark what thou hast done. Thou hast endanger'd the safety of our party; thou hast broke my order (tis not the first time, by many) in attacking a passenger:—and what passenger? One whose unhappy case should have claim'd thy pity. He told you he had displeased his master—left the house of comfort, and with his scanty pittance, was wandering round the world to mend his fortune. Like a butcher, you struck the forlorn boy to the earth, and left him to languish in the forest. Would any of our brave comrades have done this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: —None! None!

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Comrades, in this case, my voice is single. But if it have any weight, this brute, this Orson, shall be thrust from our community, which he has disgraced. Let it not be said, brothers, while want drives us to plunder, that wantonness prompts us to butchery.

sp.speaker: Robbers.
sp.p: O brave Captain! away with him!

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: You had better ponder on't, ere you provoke me.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Rascal! do you mutter threats. You cannot terrify us. Our calling teems with danger—we are not to be daunted by the treachery of an informer. We defy you. Go. Yon dare not hurt us. You dare not sacrifice so many brave, and gallant fellows, to your revenge, and proclaim yourself scoundrel. Begone.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Well, if I must, I must. I was always a friend to you all: but if you are bent on turning me out—why—fare you well.

sp.speaker: Robbers.
sp.p: Aye, aye—Away, away.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Farewell then. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Come, comrades—Think no more of this. Let us drown the choler we have felt in wine and revelry.

lg.head: FINALE.
lg.l: Jolly Friars tippled here,
Ere these Abbey walls had crumbled;
Still the ruins boast good cheer,
Though long ago the cloysters tumbled.
The Monks are gone:—
Well! well!
That's all one:—
Let's ring their knell.
Ding dong! ding dong! to the bald-pated monk!
He set the example,
We'll follow his sample,
And all go to bed most religiously drunk.
Peace to the good fat Friar's soul!
Who every day,
Did wet his clay,
In the deep capacious bowl.
Huzza! Huzza! we'll drink and we'll sing!
We'll laugh, and we'll quaff,
And make the welkin ring!

div2.stage: WINTERTON's Room, in SIR EDWARD MORTIMER's Lodge.
SAMSON and BLANCH, discover'd, at a Table, with Bottle and Glasses.

sp.speaker: BLANCH.
sp.p: SAMSON, you must drink no more.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: One more glass, Mistress Blanch, and I shall be better company. 'Twill make me loving.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Nay, then, you shall not have a drop.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: I will:—and so shall you too. filling the glass Who knows but it may make you the same?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: You are wond'rous familiar, Mr Lout.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: I would not willingly offend. I will endeavour at more respect. My humble duty to you. drinks.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I would counsel you to be cautious of drinking, Samson. Consider where you are. We are now, remember, in Sir Edward Mortimer's Lodge.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: In the Butler's room;—where drinking has always a privilege. fills.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: What, another!

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Do not fear. 'Twill not make me familiar again. My lowly respects to yon. drinks. This same old Winterton's wine has a marvellous choice flavour. I wonder whether 'twas smuggled.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Should you totter with this, now, in the morning, 'twould go nigh to shake your office to the foundation, before night. My Lady would never pardon you.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: 'Twould be hard to turn me adrift, for getting drunk, on the second day of my service.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Truly, I think 'twould be reason sufficient.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: 'Twould not be giving a man a fair trial. How should she know but I intend to be sober for a year after?

sp.speaker: Blanch,
sp.p: How should she know, indeed! or any one else, who has heard of your former rogueries.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Well, the worst fault I had was being a sportsman.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: A sportsman! out on you, rogue! you were a poacher.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Aye, so the rich nick-name us poor brothers of the field; and lay us by the heels when we do that for hunger which they practise for amusement. Cannot I move you to take a thimble-full, this cold morning?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Not a drop, I

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Hark! I think I hear old Winterton coming back. By our lady, Mistress Blanch, we have made a desperate hole in the bottle, since he left us.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: We! why, you slanderous rogue, I have not tasted it.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: No—'tis not he.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: No matter; he will be back on the instant. Leave this idle guzzling, if you have any shame. Think we are attending madam Helen, in her visit to Sir Edward, on his sudden sickness. Think, too, on the confusion from Wilford's flight. Is it a time for you, so, to tipple, when the whole house is in distress and melancholy?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Alas! I have too tender a heart, Mistress Blanch; and have need of somewhat, in the midst of this sorrow, to cheer my spirits

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: This wine will shortly give your profession of amendment the lie.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Let it give me the lie: 'Tis an affront I can easily swallow. Come, a bargain—an you will take one glass with me, I will give over.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Well, on that condition—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Agreed— for that will just finish the bottle. fills. I will drink no health, now, but of thy giving.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Then listen and edify.—May a man never insult a woman with his company, when drunkenness has made him a brute!

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: With all my heart:—But a woman knows that man may be made a brute, when wine is clean out of the question. Eh! Here comes the old man, in real earnest.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Well, I am here again.—What madcap? —In truth, I have a world of care. Our good master taken ill on a sudden. Wilford flown:—A base, ungrateful boy!—One that I was so fond of:—And to prove such a profligate! I began to love the young villain like my own child. I had mark'd down the unfortunate boy, in my last testament: I had— Bless me! my cold is wondrous troublesome to my eyes, this morning. Ah! 'tis a wicked world:— But old Winterton keeps a merry heart still. Do I not, pretty mistress Blanch?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I hope you do, Adam.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Nay, on second thought, I do not keep it; for thou hast stolen it from me, tulip! ha! good ifaith!—

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—Well ifaith that is a good jest! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Dost think so, varlet? "Thou hast stolen it from me, tulip!" Well, it was; it was exceeding pleasant, by St. Thomas! Heigho! I must e'en take a glass to console me. One cup to—eh! mercy on me! why the liquor has flown. Ha! the bottle has leak'd, haply.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Yes, Sir:—I crack'd that bottle, myself, in your absence.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Crack'd! Why what a careless goose art thou! these unthrifty knaves!—ah▪ times are sadly changed for the worse, since I was a boy.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Dost think so, Adam?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Question any man, of my age, and he will say the same. Domesticks never broke bottles in queen Elizabeth's time. Servants were better then— aye, marry, and the bottles were better bottles. 'Tis a degenerate world! Well; heigho!

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Why dost sigh thus, Adam?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: In truth, this is as heavy a day for me!—

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I hope not, Adam. Gome, come, things are not so bad, I warrant thee. You have long drank smilingly of the cup of life, Adam; and when a good man takes his potion without murmuring, Providence seldom leaves the bitterest drop at the bottom. What is the matter, Adam?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Alas! nothing but evil. These attacks come on our worthy master as thick as hail, and weaken him daily. He has been grievous ill, in the night, poor soul! and ne'er slept a wink since I brought him the news.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: What news, good Adam?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Why of Wilford's flight!—A reprobate! The shock of his baseness has brought on Sir Edward's old symptoms.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: What call you his old symptoms?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: The shivering, and trembling its, which have troubled him these two years. I begin to think the air of this forest doth nourish agues. I can never move him to drink enough of canary. I think, in my conscience, I had been aguish myself, in these woods, had I not drank plenty of canary.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Mass, when I am ill, this old boy shall be my apothecary. aside.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Well, well, he may mend. Do not fancy the worst, ere worse arrives, Adam.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Nay, worse has arrived already. Blanch. Aye! marry, how?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Wilford's villany. Sir Edward says, he has proofs of the blackest treachery against him.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p:
It chills my blood to think on't! I had mark'd out the boy as a boy of promise—A learned
boy! He had the backs of all the books in our library by heart: and now a hue and cry is after him. Mercy on me! if the wretched lad be taken, Sir Edward will bring him to the charge. We none know what 'tis yet; but time will shew.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: You surprise me! Wilford turn dishonest! I could scarce have credited this; and after two years trial, too.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: O, monstrous! to turn rogue after two years! Had it happened after two days, indeed, 'twere not to be wonder'd at.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Mr. Winterton, there is a young woman of the forest, would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Out on't! These cottagers time their business vilely. Well, bid her come in, Simon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: And, Mistress Blanch, your lady would see you anon, in the breakfast parlour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I come quickly. Be not cast down, now, Adam; keep thy old heart merry still.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Ha! in truth, I know not well, now, what would mend my spirits.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: What think you of the kiss I promis'd?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Ah, wag! go thy way Od! thou hast nimble legs. Had I o'ertaken thee yesterday—Ah! well, no matter.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Come, I will not leave thee comfortless, in these sad times Here—Here is my hand, Adam.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Thou wilt shew me a light pair of heels again, now.

sp.speaker: Blanch
sp.p: No, in faith. Come; 'tis more than I would offer to every one. Take it.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: That I will, most willingly. Kisses her hand.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p:
Do not play the rake now, and boast of my favours; for I am told there is a breed of puppies will build stories, to a simple girl's prejudice, on
slighter encouragement than this. Be not you one of those empty coxcombs, and so adieu, Adam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Nay, I was never given to vaunt. 'Sbud! if I had, many a tale had been told, sixty years back, of young, lusty Adam Winterton.—Eh! why what dost thou titter at, scapegrace?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: I, sir?—Not I smothering a laugh.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: I had forgot this varlet. Pestilence on't I Should this knave prate of my little gallantry, I tremble for the good name of poor Mistress Blanch!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: May I come in, good your worship?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Aye, marry, that thou may'st, pretty one. —Well, though many things have declined, since I was a boy, female-beauty keeps its rank still. I do think there be more pretty women now than there were in Queen Elizabeth's reign.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Flesh! this is our Barbara. aside.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Well, and what wouldst have, sweet one, with old Adam—Eh! by St. Thomas, why thou art she I have seen, ere now, with Wilford.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Beseech you, tell me where he is, sir?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Alas, child, he's gone—flown! Eh? what —why art not well, child?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Nothing, sir—I only—I hoped he would have called at our cottage, ere he quitted the forest. Is there no hope that he may come back, sir?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: None, truly, except force bring him back. Alas, child! the boy has turn'd out naught; and justice is dogging him at the heels.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: What Wilford, sit?—my poor—O, sir, my heart is bursting! I pray you, pardon me. Had he pass'd our cottage in his flight, I would have ran out, and follow'd him all the world over.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: To see what love will do! Just so did Jane Blackthorn take on for me, when Sir Marmaduke carried me to London, in the hard winter.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Beseech you, forgive me, sir! I only came to make enquiry, for I had heard a strange tale. I would not have my sorrows make me troublesome to your worship.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: To me? poor wench! nay, that thou art not. I trust, child, I never turned a deaf ear, yet, to the unfortunate. 'Tis man's office to listen to the sorrows of a woman, and do all he can to soothe them. Come, come, dry thy tears, chicken.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I look'd to have been his wife shortly, sir. He was as kind a youth—And, I am sure, he wanted not gratitude. I have heard him talk of you, as you were his father, sir.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Did he? Ah! poor lad. Well, he had good qualities; but, alas! he is now a reprobate. Poor boy! To think, now, that he should speak kindly of the old man, behind his back!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Alas, this is the second flight to bring unhappiness to our poor family!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: The second! How do'st mean, wench?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: My brother, sir, left our cottage suddenly, yesterday morning; and we have no tidings of him since.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Lo you, now, where he stands, to glad the hearts of his disconsolate relations! Sister Barbara, why dost not know me?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Eh! No—Sure it can't—Brother Samson?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Mr. Samson—Head serving man to the Lady Helen, of the New Forest.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O, the fortune! can it be! what gain'd thee so good a place, Samson?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Merit. I had no interest to back me. Mine is a rare case—I was promoted on the score of my virtues.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Out upon thee! thy knaveries have been the talk of the whole forest; and furnish'd daily food for conversation.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Truly, then, conversation has fared better upon them than I. But my old character is laid aside with my old jerkin. I am now exalted.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: An I have any forecast in destiny, friend, thou bidst fair, one day, to be more exalted.— Ha! good ifaith! Come, you must to the kitchen, knave. I must thither myself, to give order for the day.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Must I return home, then, your worship, with no tidings?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Ah! heaven help me! what havock doth wanton Cupid make with us all! Well, tarry about the house, with thy brother; we may hear somewhat, haply, anon. Take care of thy sister, knave; and mark what I have said to thee.—"Thou bidst fair one day to be more exalted." Had well, it was exceeding pleasant, by St. Thomas!Exit.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Well, Barbara, and how fares father?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: He has done nought but chide, since you disappear'd, Samson. It has sour'd him with us all.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Well, I will call, soon, and set all even.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Will yuo, brother?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: I will. Bid him not be cast down. I will protect the Rawbold family.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Truly, brother, we are much in need of protection.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Do not fear. Lean upon my power. I am head of all the male domesticks, at Madam Helen's.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O, the father! of all! and how many be there, brother?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Why, truly, not so many as there be at the Lodge, here. But I have a boy under me, to chop wood, and draw water.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: The money we had from Sir Edward's bounty, is nearly gone in payment of the debt our father owed. You know he had shortly been imprison'd, else.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: My stock is somewhat low, too.—But, no matter. Keep a good heart. I am now a rising man. I will make you all comfortable.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Heaven bless you, Samson!

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: In three months, I look for a quarter's wages; and then Dick shall have a shirt. I must now take you roundly to task.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Me, brother!

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Aye, marry. You would throw yourself away on this Wilford—who▪ as the story goes, is little better than the devil's own imp.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O, brother! be not so uncharitable. I know not what is against him, but he has not been heard yet. Consider too—were all our actions, at home, to be sifted, I fear me, we might not escape blameless.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Aye, but he, it seems, is falling, and we are upon the rise; and that makes all the difference. Mass! how gingerly men will sift the faults of those who are getting up hill in the world; and what a rough shake they give those who are going downward!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I would not be one of those sisters, brother.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: No,—I warrant, now, thou wouldst marry this vagabond.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: That I would, brother. He has cheer'd me in my distress, and I would sooner die than leave him, now he is unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Hast thou no respect for the family? Thou wilt bring endless disgrace on the name of Rawbold. Shame on you! to take away from our reputation, when we have so little!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I thought, brother, you would have shewn more pity for your poor sister.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Tush! Love's a mere vapour.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Ah! brother.

lg.head: DUETT.
SAMSON and BARBARA.
I.
lg.l: From break of the morning, were I with my love,
I'd talk till the evening drew nigh;
And, when the day did close,
I'd sing him to repose,
And tune my love a lullaby.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: From break of the morning, were I with my love,
O! long ere the evening drew nigh,
Her talk would make me dose,
Till the musick of my nose
Would play my love a lullaby.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Our children around us, I'd look on my love,
Each moment in rapture would fly.
But love is apt to pall,
When the brats begin to squall,
And a wife is screaming lullaby.
From break of the mornings, &c,

div2.stage: A Room in Sir EDWARD MORTIMER's Lodge.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Sooth, you look better now; indeed you do.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Thou'rt a sweet flatterer!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Ne'er trust me, then,
If I do flatter. This is wilfulness.—
Thou wilt be sick, because thou wilt be sick.
I'll laugh away this fancy, Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What couldst thou do to laugh away my sickness?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I'll mimick the physician—wise and dull—
With cane at nose, and nod emphatical,
Portentous in my silence; feel your pulse,
With an owl's face, that shall express as much
As Galen's head, cut out in wood, and gilt,
Stuck over an apothecary's door.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: And what wouldst thou prescribe?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I would distil
Each flower that lavish happiness produced.
Through the world's paradise, ere Disobedience
Scatter'd the seeds of care; then mingle each,
In one huge cup of comfort for thee, love,
To chase away thy dulness. Thou shouldst wanton
Upon the wings of Time, and mock his flight,
As he sail'd with thee tow'rd Eternity.
I'd have each hour, each minute of thy life,
A golden holiday; and should a cloud
O'ercast thee, be it light as a gossamer,
That Helen might disperse it with a breath,
And talk thee into sunshine!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Sweet, sweet Helen!
Death, soften'd with thy voice, might dull his sting,
And steep his darts in balsam. Oh! my Helen,
These warnings which that grisly monarch sends,
Forerunners of his certain visitation,
Of late are frequent with me. It should seem
I was not meant to live long.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Mortimer!
My Mortimer! You—Oh! for heaven's sake,
Do not talk thus! You chill me. You are well;
Very well.—You give way—Oh, Mortimer!
Banish these fantasies. Think on poor Helen!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Think on thee, Helen?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Aye: but not think thus.
You said, my Mortimer, my voice could soothe,
In the most trying struggle.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Said I so?
Yet, Helen, when my fancy paints a death-bed,
I ever place thee foremost in the scene,
To make the picture touching. After man
Is summon'd, and has made up his account,
Oh! 'tis a bitter after-reck'ning, when
His pallid lips receive the last, sad kiss,
Fond, female anguish prints! Then, Helen, then,
Then comes man's agony! To leave the object
He shelter'd in his heart, grief-struck and helpless;
To grasp her hand; to fix his hollow eye
Upon her face, and mark her mute despair,
'Till the last flutter of his aching spirit
Hurries him hence, for ever!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh! for pity—
What have I done, that you— bursts into tears.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: My Helen!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I did not mean to weep. Oh, Mortimer,
I could not talk so cruelly to you!
I would not pain you thus, for worlds!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Nay, come;
I meant not this▪ I did not mean to say
There's danger now; but 'tis the privilege
Of sickness to be grave, and moralize
On that which sickness brings. I prithee, now,
Be comforted. Believe me, I shall mend.
I feel I shall already.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Do you, Mortimer?
Do you, indeed, feel so?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Indeed I do.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I knew you would:—I said it. Did I not?
I'am so glad! You must be cautious now.—
I'll play the nurse to-day—and then, to-morrow,
You shall not brood at home, as you are wont,
But we will ride together, through the forest.
You must have exercise. Oh! I will make you
Fresh as the summer dew-drop, and as healthy
As ruddy Labour, springing from his bed,
To carol o'er the fallow!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Dearest prattler!
Men would meet sickness with a smiling welcome,
Were all woo'd back to health thus prettily.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I see it in your looks, now, you are better▪

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Scarce possible, so suddenly!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: O, yes;
There is no little movement of your face
But I can mark on the instant—'Tis my study.
I have so gaz'd upon it, that, I think,
I can interpret ev'ry turn it has,
And read your inmost soul.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Mercy on me!
You change again.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: 'Twas nothing. Do not fear;
These little shocks are usual.—'Twill not last.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Would you could shake them off!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I would I could!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Resolve it, then; and the bare resolution
Will bring the remedy. Rally your spirits;
I prithee, now, endeavour.—This young man,
This boy—this Wilford—he has been ungrateful;
But do not let his baseness wear you thus.
Ev'n let him go.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I'll hunt him through the world!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Why, look you there now! Pray be calm.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Well, well;
I am too boisterous: 'Tis my unhappiness
To seem most harsh where I would shew most kind.
The world has made me peevish. This same boy
Has somewhat moved me.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: He's beneath your care.
Seek him not now, to punish him. Poor wretch!
He carries that away, within his breast,
Which will embitter all his life to come,
And make him curse the knowledge on't.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: The knowledge!—
Has he then breathed—Carries within his breast!
What does he know?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: His own ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: O, very true.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Then leave him to his Conscience.
It is a scorpion, sent by Heaven itself,
To fix on hidden crimes; a flow, still stream,
Of moulten lead, kept dropping on the heart,
To scald and weigh it down. Believe me, love,
There is no earthly punishment so great,
To scourge an evil act, as man's own conscience,
To tell him he is guilty.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: 'Tis a hell!
I pray you talk no more on't.—I am weak—
I did not sleep last night.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Would you sleep now?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: No, Helen, no. I tire thy patient sweetness.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Tire me! nay, that you do not. You forget
How often I have sat by you, and watch'd,
Fanning the busy summer-flies away,
Lest they should break your slumbers. Who comes here?
What, Winterton! How do'st thou, old acquaintance?
How dost thou, Adam?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Bless your goodness, well.
Is my good master better?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Somewhat, Adam.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Now, by our lady, I rejoice to hear it!
I have a message—

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: O, no business now!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Nay, so I said. Quoth I, his honour's sick;
Perilous sick! but the rogue press'd, and press'd;
I could refuse no longer. Out upon them!
The varlets know old Winterton's good nature.
'Tis my weak side.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Who has thus importuned you?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: To say the truth, a most ill-favour'd varlet.
But he will speak to none but to his worship.
I think 'tis forest business.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O, not now:
Another time—to-morrow—when he will.
I am unfit.—They teize me!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Ev'n as you please, your worship. I should think,
From what he dropt, he can give some account
Of the poor boy.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Of Wilford!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Troth, I think so.
The knave is shy; but Adam has a head.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Quick; send him hither on the instant! Haste!
Fly, Adam, fly!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Well now, it glads my heart
To hear you speak so briskly.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Well, dispatch!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: I go. Heaven bless you both! Heaven send you well,
And merry days may come again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I fear this business may distract you, Mortimer:
I would you would defer it till to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Not so, sweet. Do not fear. I prithee now,
Let me have way in this. Retire awhile.
Anon I'll come to thee.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Pray now, be careful.
I dread those agitations. Pray, keep calm.
Now do not tarry long. Adieu, my Mortimer!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Farewel, awhile, sweet!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Since it must be so—
Farewel!Exit Helen.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Dear, simple innocence! thy words of comfort
Pour oil upon my fires. Methought her eye,
When first she spake of conscience, shot a glance
Like her dead uncle on me. Well, for Wilford!
That slave can play the Parthian with my fame,
And wound it while he flies. Bring him before me,
Place me the runagate within my gripe,
And I will plant my honour on its base,
Firmer than adamant, tho' hell and death
Should moat the work with blood! Oh, how will sin
Engender sin! Throw guilt upon the soul,
And, like a rock dash'd on the troubled lake,
'Twill form its circles, round succeeding round,
Each wider than the—
How now! What's your business?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Part with your office in the forest: part
Concerns yourself in private.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: How myself?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Touching a servant of your house; a lad,
Whose heels, I find, were nimbler than his duty.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Speak; what of him? Quick—Know you where he is?
Canst bring me to him?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: To the very spot.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Do it.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Nay, softly.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: I'll reward you—amply—
Ensure your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: First ensure my neck.
'Twill do me little good else. I've no heirs;
And, when I die, 'tis like the law will bury me,
At its own charge.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Be brief, and to your purpose.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Then, to the business which concerns your office,
Here, in the forest.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Nay, of that anon,
First of my servant.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Well, ev'n as you please.
'Tis no rare thing—Let public duty wait,
'Till private interests are settled▪ But
My story is a chain. Take all together,
'Twill not unlink.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Be quick, then. While we talk,
This slave escapes me.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Little fear of that.
He's in no plight to journey far to-day.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Where is he hid?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Hard by; with robbers.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Robber!—
Well, I'm glad on't. 'Twill suit my purpose best.
—What, has he turn'd to plunder?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: No; not so.
Plunder has turn'd to him. He was knock'd down,
Last night, here in the forest, flat and sprawling;
And the milk-hearted captain of our gang
Has shelter'd him.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: It seems, then, thou'rt a thief?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I serv'd in the profession: But, last night,
The scurvy rogues cashier'd me. 'Twas a plot,
To ruin a poof fellow in his calling,
And take away my means of getting bread.
I come here, in revenge. I'll hang my comrades,
In clusters, on the forest oaks, like acorns.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Where lies their haunt?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Give me your honour, first—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I pledge it, for your safety.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Send your officers
To the old abbey ruins; you will find
As bold a gang as e'er infested woods,
And fatten'd upon pillage.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: What, so near me!
In some few minutes, then, he's mine! Ho! Wintetton!
Now for his lurking place! Hope dawns again.
Remain you here; I may have work for you.
O! I will weave a web so intricate,
For this base insect! so entangle him!—
Why, Winterton!—Thou jewel, reputation!
Let me secure thee, bright and spotless, now;
And this weak, care-worn body's dissolution,
Will cheaply pay the purchase! Winterton!Exit.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: There may be danger in my stay here. I will e'en slink off, in the confusion I have rais'd. I value not the reward. I hang my comrades, and that shall content me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Rare scuttling tow'rd! This lodge is little Babel:
And Spleen and Sickness are the household gods,
In this, my brother's, castle of confusion.
The hue and cry is up! I am half tempted
To wish the game too nimble for the dogs,
That hunt him at the hells. Dishonest! Well,
I'll ne'er trust looks again. His face hangs out
A goodly sign; but all within, it seems,
Is dirty rooms, stale eggs, prick'd wine, sour beer.
Rank bacon, musty beef, and tallow candles.
I'll be deceived no more.—I'll mix with none,
In future but the ugly: honest men,
Who can out-grin a Griffin; or the head
Carved on the prow of the good ship the Gorgon.
I'm for carbuncled, weather-beaten faces,
That frighten little children, and might serve
For knockers to hall gates.—Now—who are you?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Head serving man to madam Helen, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, I may talk to thee; for thou dost answer
To the description of the sort of men
I have resolved to live with.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.l: I am proud, Sir,
To find I have your countenance.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Can'st tell me
The news of Wilford?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.l: He is turn'd a rogue, Sir,
An errant knave, Sir. 'Tis a rare thing, now,
To find an honest servant:—We are scarce.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Where lies the Abbey where they go to seek him?
Dost know it?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.l: Marry, do I; in the dark.
I have stood near it, many a time, in winter,
