To watch the hares▪ by moonlight.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: A cold pastime!

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.p: Aye, Sir; 'twas killing work. I've left it off.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Think you they will be back soon?

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.l: On the instant:
It is hard by, Sir.—Hark I hear their horses!
They are return'd, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Run you, fellow,—
If Wilford's taken, send him here to me.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.l: Why he's a rogue, Sir. Would your worship stoop
To parley with a rogue!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Friend, I will stoop
To prop a sinking man, that's call'd a rogue,
And count him innocent, 'till he's found guilty.
I learn'd it from our English laws; where mercy
Models the weights that fill the scales of Justice,
And Charity, when Wisdom gives her sentence,
Stands by to prompt her. 'Till detection comes,
I side with the accused.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.l: Would I had known
Your worship sooner. You're a friend, indeed!
All undiscover'd rogues are bound to pray for you:
—So, Heaven bless you!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, well—bustle; stir:—
Do as I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Sams.
sp.l: Aye Sir.—I shall lean
Upon your worship in any time of need.—
Heaven reward you! —Here's a friend to make!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I have a kind of movement, still, for Wilford,
I cannot conquer. What can be this charge
Sir Edward brings against him?—Should the boy
Prove guilty!—well; why should I pity guilt?
Philosophers would call me driv'ler.—Let them.
Whip a deserter, and philosophy
Stands by, and says he merits it. That's true:—
But wherefore should philosophy take snuff,
When the poor culprit writhes? A plague on stoicks!
I cannot hoop my heart about with iron,
Like an old beer-butt. I would have the vessel
What some call weak:—I'd have it ooze a little.
Better compassion should be set abroach,
'Till it run waste, than let a system-monger
Bung it with Logick; or a trencher cap
Bawl out his ethics on it, 'till his thunder
Turn all the liquor sour.—So! Here he comes!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I am inform'd it is your pleasure, Sir,
To speak with me.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye, Wilford. I am sorry—
Faith, very sorry,—you and I meet thus.
How could you quit my brother thus abruptly?
Was he unkind to you?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Most bountiful.
He made me all I am. The poor can number
His virtues thick as stars. I owe him, Sir,
A world of gratitude.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: 'Tis a new mode
Of payment you have taken. Wherefore fly?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: I was unfit to serve him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Unfit!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I was unhappy, Sir. I fled a house
Where certain misery awaited me,
While I was doom'd to dwell in't.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Misery!
What was this certain misery?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Your pardon,—
I never will divulge.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: No, never.
Pray do not press me. All that I can say
Is, that I have a strong, and rooted reason,
Which has resolved me. 'Twere impossible
I should be tranquil here. I feel it, Sir,
A duty to myself to quit this roof.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Harkye, young man. This smacks of mystery;
And now looks foully. Truth, and Innocence,
Walk round the world in native nakedness.
But guilt is cloak'd.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Whate'er the prejudice
My conduct conjures up, I must submit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: 'Twere better now you conjured up your friends:
For I must tell you—No, there is no need.
You learn'd it, doubtless, on the way, and know
The danger you, now, stand in.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Danger, Sir!
What? How? I have learn'd nothing, Sir; my guides
Drag'd me in silence hither.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Then 'tis fit
I put you on your guard. It grieves me, Wilford,
To say there is a heavy charge against you,
Which, as I gather, may affect your life.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Mine!—O, good Heaven!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Pray be calm:—for, soon,
Here, in the face of all his family,
My brother will accuse you.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: He!—What, He!
He accuse me! O monstrous! O, look down
You who can read mens hearts!—A charge against me!
Ha! ha! I'm innocent! I'm innocent!much agitatated

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Collect your firmness. You will need it all.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I shall, indeed! I pray you tell me, Sir,
What is the charge?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I do not know its purport.
I would not hear on't: for on my voice rests
The issue of this business;—and a judge
Should come unbiass'd to his office. Wilford,
Were twenty brothers waiting my award,
You should have even, and impartial justice.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: O, you are just! I would all men were so!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I hope most men are so. Rally your thoughts.
When you are call'd upon! if truth will serve you,
Sketch out your story with her chaste, bold pencil;
If truth should fail you, Wilford, even take
The fairest colour human art can mix,
To give a glow to plausibility.
Tis self-defence; and 'tis allow'd, when man
Must battle it, with all the world against him.
—Heaven bless you, boy!—that is, I mean— pshaw! plague!
—Farewell! and may you prosper?Exit.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Then, all my youthful hopes are blighted in the bud! The breath of my powerful persecutor will wither them. Let me recall my actions.—My breast is unclog'd with crime. This charge is to be open;—in the eye of the world; of the laws —Then, why should I fear? I am native of a happy soil where justice guards equally the life of its poorest and richest inhabitant. Let him inflict his menaces upon me, in secret; Let him torture my mind and body; he shall not, cannot, touch my good name.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O, Wilford!falls on his neck

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Barbara! at such a time, too!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: To be brought back, thus, Wilford! and to go away without seeing me! without thinking of me!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: It was not so.—I was hastening to your cottage, Barbara, when a ruffian, in the forest, encounter'd and wounded me.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Wounded you!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Be not alarm'd 'Tis not, as I thought yesternight, of moment. One of his party took me to the Abbey ruins, and gave me timely succour.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: And, was it so! was it so, Wilford?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Aye, Barbara. When I was drag'd hither, the whole troop escaped, or they had vouch'd for the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I would they had not escaped. For all here say that you had fled to join them.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: What! join with robbers! what next shall I be charged with!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Bethink you, Wilford—the time is short: I know your heart is good; but—
But what? Can you suspect it, too, Barbara!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O! mine is so link'd with it, that I would follow you through beggary, through prisons, Wilford.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Prison! The sound, now, makes me shudder!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: If in a hasty moment you have done aught to wrong Sir Edward, throw yourself on his mercy; —sue for pardon.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: For pardon!—I shall go mad! Pardon! I am innocent.—Heaven knows I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Heaven be thank'd!—The family is all summon'd. O, Wilford! my spirits sink within me.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: aside I am, now, but a sorry comforter. —Come, Barbara; be tranquil. You see I am so. Don't—don't you, Barbara?agitated

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: You must attend in the next room.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: What, Walter, is it you? Pray tell me if—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Do not question me. I hold no discourse with any of your stamp.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Your tone is strangely changed on the sudden. What have I done?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: You are going to be tried. That's enough for me.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: I might rather claim your pity on that score, Walter.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: What, pity a man that's going to be tried? O, monstrous!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Well, fare you well. I will not upbraid you, Walter. You have many in the world to countenance you. Blacken well your neighbour, and nine in ten are in haste to cry shame upon him, ere he has time, or opoprtunity, to wipe off the accusation. I follow you.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Do so. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p:
Be of good cheer. I go arm'd in honesty, Barbara. I can bear every thing. Every thing, save
making you the partner of my misfortunes. That, Barbara—I am sure you love me——That would give me a pang which would—Farewell!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Alas! I tremble for his safety! should they tear him from me!——

lg.l: DOWN by the river there grows a green willow;
Sing all for my true love! my true love, O!
I'll weep out the night there, the bank for my pillow;
And all for my true love, my true love, O!
When bleak blows the wind, and tempests are beating,
Ill count all the clouds, as I mark them retreating,
For true lovers joys, well a-day! are as fleeting.
Sing, O for my true love, &c.
Maids come, in pity, when I am departed;
Sing all for my true love, &c.
When dead, on the bank, I am found broken hearted,
And all for my true love, &c.
Make me a grave, all while the wind's blowing,
Close to the stream, where my tears once were flowing,
And over my corse keep the green willow growing.
'Tis all for my true love, &c.

div2.stage: FITZ-HARDING, WILFORD, and various domesticks, discovered.—To them enter ADAM WINTERTON.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Is not Sir Edward coming, Adam?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Aye, Sir.—
But he is grievous ill.—Since Wilford came,
He had another fit.—But he'll be here.
Ah, boy! that I should live to see this day!
I have a merry heart no longer, now.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Good man! you have been ever kind to me.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Heav'n send you may prove honest! Heav'n send it!
—Here comes Sir Edward. Would that I had died
Two reigns ago!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Now, brother.—You look pale,
And faint with sickness.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Here's a chair, your worship.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: No matter.—To our business, brother Wilford,
You may well guess the struggle I endure
To place you here the mark of accusation.
I gave you ample warning: Caution'd you,
When many might have scourged: and, even now,
While I stand here to crush you,—aye, to crush you,—
My heart bleeds drops of pity for your youth,
Whose rashness plucks the red destruction down,
And pulls the bolt upon you.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: You know best
The movements of your heart, sir. Man is blind,
And cannot read them: but there is a Judge,
To whose all seeing eye our inmost thoughts
Lye open. Think to him you, now, appeal.—
Omniscience keeps heaven's register;
And, soon or late, when Time unfolds the book,
Our trembling souls must answer to the record,
And meet their due reward or punishment.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Now, to the point, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Thus it is, then.
I do suspect—By heaven the story lingers,
Like poison, on my tongue,—but he will force it—

sp.speaker: Fitz
sp.p: What is it you suspect?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: —That he has rob'd me.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Rob'd! I! O, horrible!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Not yet—not yet.
Pray tell me, brother—I will be impartial;—
But I am somewhat moved.—Pray tell me, brother,
How ground you this suspicion!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Briefly, thus.——
You may have noticed, in my library,
A chest Wilford starts—You see he changes at the word.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: And well I may!aside.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Where I have told you, brother,
The writings which concern our family,
With jewels, cash, and other articles,
Of no mean value, were deposited.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: You oftentimes have said so.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Yesterday,
Chance call'd me, suddenly away: I left
The key in't—but as suddenly return'd;
And found this Wilford, this young man, whose state,
Whose orphan state, met pity in my house,
'Till pity grew to friendship,—him I found,
Fix'd o'er the chest, upon his knees, intent,
As, now, I think, on plunder; tinging theft
Still blacker with ingratitude; and rifling
The easy fool who shelter'd him. Confusion
Shook his young joints, as he let fall the lid,
And gave me back the key.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Did you not search
Your papers on the instant?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: No:—for, first,
(Habit so long had fix'd my confidence)
I deem'd it boyish curiosity;—
But told him this would meet my further question:
And, at that moment, came a servant in,
To say you were arrived. He must have mark'd
Our mix'd emotion.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Is that servant here?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: 'Twas I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Was it you? Well, saw you aught
To challenge your attention?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Sir, I did.
Wilford was pale and trembling; and our master
Gave him a look as if 'twould pierce him through;
And cried, "Remember."—Then he trembled more,
And we both quitted him.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: When first we met,
You found me somewhat ruffled.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: 'Tis most true.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: But somewhat more when, afterwards, I saw
Wilford conversing with you—like a snake,
Sun'd by your looks, and basking in your favour.
I bade him quit the room, with indignation,
And wait my coming in the library.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: I witness'd that, with wonder.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O, good brother!
You little thought, while you so gently school'd me,
In the full flow of your benevolence,
For my harsh bearing tow'rd him, on what ground
That harshness rested. I had made my search,
In the brief interval of absence from you,
And found my property had vanish'd.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: We'll—
You met him in the library?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O never
Can he forget that solemn interview!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Aye, speak to that:—it was a solemn interview.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Observe, he does acknowledge that we met▪
Guilt was my theme:—he cannot now deny it.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: It was a theme of—No. checking himself.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: He pleaded innocence:
While every word he spake belied his features,
And mock'd his protestation. I restrain'd
The chastisement he fear'd; nor wou'd I blazon
The wrong I could not fix; and subject, thus,
By general inquiry, all the guiltless
To foul suspicion. That suspicion lay
Most heavily on him; but the big cloud
Of anger he had gather'd burst not on him,
In vengeance to o'erwhelm him: chill it drop'd,
But kindly, as the dew, in admonition;
Like tears of fathers o'er a wayward child,
When love enforces them to ruggedness.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: What said you to him?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: "Regulate your life,
"In future, better. I, now, spare your youth;
"But dare not to proceed. All I exact,
"('Tis a soft penance)—that you tarry here,
"My eye your guard, my house your gentle prison,
"My bounty be your chains. Attempt not flight;
"Flight ripens all my doubt to certainty,
"And justice to the world unlocks my tongue."—
He fled, and I arraign him.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Trust me, brother,
This charge is staggering. Yet accidents
Sometimes combine to cast a shade of doubt
Upon the innocent. May it be so here!
Here is his trunk: 'twas brought here at my order.
'Tis fit that it be search'd.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O, that were needless.
He were a shallow villain that would trust
His freight of plunder to so frail a bottom.
School-boys, who strip the orchard of its fruit,
Conceal their thievery better.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Yet 'tis found,
Such negligence is often link'd with guilt.
—Take not—I say not yet that he is guilty,
But scarce heard of crafty villain, yet,
Who did not make some blot in his foul game,
That lookers-on have thought him blind, and mad,
It was so palpable.—'Tis rarely otherwise:
Heaven's hand is in it, brother: Providence
Marks guilt, as 'twere, with a fatuity.—
Adam, do you inspect it. to Winterton.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Here's the key—
E'en take it, freely.—You'll find little there
I value; save a locket, which my mother
Gave me upon her death-bed; and she added
Her blessing to't. Perhaps, her spirit now
Is grieving for my injuries.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: after opening the trunk. O, mercy!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: How now? What's there?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: As I'm a wretched man,
The very watch my good old master wore!
And, here, my lady's jewels!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I am innocent.
Just Heaven hear me!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I must hear you, now.
What can you say?—Oh! Wilford.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Give me breath.
Let me collect myself. First this. falls on his knees May sleep
Ne'er close my burning eyes; may conscience gnaw me;
May engines wrench my entrails from their seat;
And whirl them to the winds before my face,
If I know aught of this!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Make it appear so.—But look there; look there!pointing to the trunk.

sp.speaker: Wilf
sp.l: Heap circumstance upon me; multiply
Charge upon charge; pile seeming fact on fact;
Still I maintain my innocence. Look at me!
Are these the throes of guilt? Are these convulsions
Of a poor, helpless friendless, wretched boy,
The struggles of a villain?—One thing more:
I here aver it—to his face aver it—
He knows—Yes, he—Yes, my accuser knows,
I merit not his charge.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: O! fie on't, fie!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Wilford, take heed! A base attempt to blacken
An injured master, will but plunge you deeper.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I know what I am doing. I repeat it:
Will die repeating it. Sir Edward Mortimer
Is conscious of my innocence.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Proceed—
Look at these proofs, and talk.—Unhappy boy,
Thy tongue can do me little mischief now.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Do you not know—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: —'Tis no matter, sir.
But I could swear—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Nay, Wilford, pause a while.
Reflect that oaths are sacred. Weigh the force
Of these asseverations. Mark it well.

l.hi: I swear by all the ties that bind a man,

sp.l: Divine or human! Think on that, and shudder.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: The very words I utter'd! I am tongue-tied. aside.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Wilford, if there be aught that you can urge,
To clear yourself, advance it.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: O, I could!
I could say much, but must not.—No, I will not.
Do as you please.—I have no friend—no witness,
Save my accuser. Did he not—pray ask him—
Did he not vaunt his wiles could ruin me?
Did he not menace, in his pride of power,
To blast my name, and crush my innocence?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: What do you answer, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: I answer—No.—
More were superflous, when a criminal
Opposes empty volubility.
To circumstantial charge. A stedfast brow
Repels not fact, nor can invalidate
These dumb, but damning, witnesses, before him.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: By the just Pow'r that rules us, I am ignorant
How they came there!—but 'tis my firm belief,
You placed them there, to sink me.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: O, too much!
You steel men's hearts against you! Death and shame!
It rouses honest choler. Call the officers.—
He shall meet punishment. Servants going.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Hold! pray you, hold.
Justice has, thus far, struggled with my pity,
To do an act of duty to the world.
I would unmask a hypocrite; lay bare
The front of guilt, that men may see and shun it:
'Tis done—And I will, now, proceed no further.
I would not hurt the serpent, but to make
The serpent hurtless. He has lost his sting.
Let him depart, and freely.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Lookye, brother.
This shall not be.—Had he proved innocent,
My friendship had been doubled; you well know
I have been partial to him—but this act
Is so begrimed with black, ungrateful malice,
That I insist on justice. Fly, knaves! run,
And let him be secured. Exeunt servants. You tarry here to Wilford.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I will not have it thus.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: You must—You shall—
'Tis weak else. Oons! I trust I have as much
Of good, straight-forward pity, as may serve;
But, to turn dove—to sit still, and be peck'd at,
It is too tame. His insolence tops all!
Does not this rouse you, too?—Look on these jewels.—
Look at this picture.—'Twas our mother's: Stay,
Let me inspect this nearer. What are here?
Parchments— inspecting the trunk.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O, look no further.—They are deeds,
Which, in his haste, no doubt he crowded there,
Not knowing what—to look o'er at his leisure—
Family deeds—They all were in my chest.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: O, 'tis deep laid!—These, too, to give a colour!aside.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: What have we here? I have your leave, good brother,
As arbiter in this. Here is a paper
Of curious enfolding—slipt, as 'twere
By chance, within another. This may be
Of note upon his trial.—What's this drops?
A knife, it seems!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What?starting.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Marks of blood upon it.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Touch it not. Throw it back!—bury it— sink it!
Oh, carelessness and haste! Give me that paper.
Darkness and hell!—Give back the paper.

div2.stage: MORTIMER attempts to snatch it; WILFORD runs between the two brothers, falls on his knees, and prevents him, holding FITZHARDING.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: rapidly No.
I see—I see!—Preserve it. You are judge!—
My innocence, my life, rests on it I

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Devils.
Foil me at my own game!—Fate!—Ha, ha, ha!
Sport, Lucifer!——He struck me —

div2.stage: MORTIMER is fainting, and falling; WILFORD runs and catches him.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I'll support him.——
Read! read! read!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: What is this?—My mind misgives me!
It is my brother's hand!—To die before me!
What can this mean?— reads.
Narrative of my murder of—Oh, great Heav'n!
"If by some chance my guilt should be disclos'd,
"May this contribute to redeem the wreck
"Of my lost honour!"—I am horror-struck!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Plain! plain!—Stay! he revives.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: What has been—soft!
I have been wand'ring with the damn'd, sure.— Brother!—
And—aye—'tis Wilford! Oh! thought flashes on me
Like Lightning. I am brain-scorch'd. Give me leave.
I will speak—Soon I will—a little yet—
Come hither, boy.—Wrong'd boy! O Wilford, Wilford!

div2.stage: bursts into tears, and falls on Wilford's neck.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Be firm, Sir; pray be firm! my heart bleeds for you—
Warms for you! Oh! all your former charity
To your poor boy, is in my mind.—Still, still,
I see my benefactor!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Well, I will—
I will be firm. One struggle, and 'tis over.
I have most foully wrong'd you! Ere I die—
And I feel death-struck—let me haste to make
Atonement.—Brother, note. The jewels,
Yes, and that paper—Heaven and accident
Ordain'd it so!—were placed—Curse on my flesh,
To tremble thus!—were placed there by my hand.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: O, mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: More. I feared this boy;
He knew my secret; and I blacken'd him,
That, should he e'er divulge the fatal story,
His word might meet no credit. Infamy
Will brand my mem'ry for't: Posterity,
Whose breath I made my god, will keep my shame
Green in her damning record. Oh! I had—
I had a heart o'erflowing with good thoughts
For all mankind! One fatal, fatal turn,
Has poison'd all! Where is my honour, now?
To die!—To have my ashes trampled on,
By the proud foot of scorn! Polluted! Hell—
Who dares to mock my guilt? Is't you—or you?
—Wrack me that grinning fiend! Damnation!
Who spits upon my grave? I'll stab again—
I'll—Oh!falls.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: This rives my heart in twain. Why, brother, brother!
His looks are ghastly.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the officers.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Away, knave! Send them hence—the boy is innocent.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: What, Wilford?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye. Tell it your fellows. Hence!—
You shall know more anon. Send in some help—
Your master's ill o' the sudden. Send some help!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: 'Twere best to raise him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Soft, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Where is he? Ill! and on the ground! Oh, Mortimer!
Oh, Heaven! my Mortimer. O, raise him.— Gently.
Speak to me, love. He cannot!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Helen—'Twas I that——

div2.stage: he struggles to speak, but appears unable to utter.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Oh, he's convulsed!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Say nothing. We must lead him to his chamber.
Beseech you to say nothing! Come, good lady.

div2.stage: FlTZHARDING and HELEN lead MORTIMER out.
Enter BARBARA, on the opposite side.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O, Wilford! I have flown to you! You are innocent.—The whole house now has it, you are innocent. Thank Heaven! Speak; tell me— How—how was it, dear, dear Wilford?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: I cannot tell you now, Barbara. Another time: But it is so.—I cannot speak now.—

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Nor I, scarce, for joy! See! hither come your fellows, to greet you. I am so happy!

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.p: Joy! Wilford.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p:
Peace, peace, I pray you. Our master is taken ill: So ill, my fellows, that I fear me he stands in much danger. That you rejoice in my acquittal, I perceive, and thank you. Sir Edward's brother will explain further to you: I cannot. But believe this:—Heaven, to whose eye the dark movements of guilt are manifest, will ever watch over,
and succour the innocent, in their extremity. Clamour not now your congratulations to me, I entreat you: Rather, let the slow, still voice of gratitude be lifted up to Providence, for that care she ever bestows upon those deserving her protection!

lg.l: Where Gratitude shall breathe the note,
To white-robed Mercy's throne,
Bid the mild strain on aether float,
A soft and dulcet tone.
Sweet, sweet and clear the accents raise,
While mellow flutes shall swell the song of praise,
Melody! Melody!
A soft and dulcet memory!
Where Fever droops his burning head;
Where sick men languish on their bed;
Around let ev'ry accent be,
Harmony! Harmony!
A soft and dulcet harmony!
